title: What should I do if I am not able to study? - Quora

response.answer_text: You first need to build your sense of direction in your studies. That means you need to be constantly aware what are the topics you already know and what are the topics still require you to spend more time to study. In order to build your sense of direction in your studies, you need to study to understand, which provides for solid memories, rather than studying to remember/memorizing. This is what I will suggest you do On school days or any busy days, allocate a fixed time for homework and studying in each day. This will give you an idea on how much time you need each day to do both which makes you more organized.For each day, ideally before you go to bed, allocate 1 hour to finish your homework and the next hour doing some short revisions from what you learned during school.The short revisions include writing some short notes of what you know and what you still need to learn from today’s lessons.In the final 5 minutes of that one hour revision session, you do a reflectionon what you have learn in all your lesson today. This meaning making a summary of what you have learned today and what you still need to learn or not sure or seek help from the teacher on the next day.By doing a reflection, you get a clear idea of what you know and don’t know which then gives you direction on what you need to learn in school. This will naturally give you a sense of purpose in studying as well as keeping you engaged in your study session. Thus, you will naturally have the motivation to keep learning and studying.During the weekends (or any full day), allocate a 2 or 3 hour study session, with a 15 minutes break in between, on each weekend for a study session. The most ideal time to do this is in the morning when you just had your breakfast. In the last 15 minutes of each study session, you also do a reflection on what you have learned and what you still need to improve on. This will give you a sense of direction on what you still need to learn in class for the next week. If you repeat this step, you will realized you are studying more efficiently by constantly focus on improvement. You may add one more 3 hour study session on a full day if you do not have anything else on. All this allows you to study efficiently and still have time to have fun, doing your fitness/exercises and have a good night sleep See Timothy Soo's answer to What are some good study habits?

I’ve always studied in a 50–10 cycle. I’ll study for 50 minutes, take a break for 10, and repeat until I’ve reached some point of exhaustion. That’s when I’ll give myself a 15–20 minute break where I literally find something to do that is not studying. If the weather’s nice I’ll take a walk at the nearby park and listen to some music to help take my mind off the topic at hand. I usually always have a book I’m in the middle of reading so sometimes I’ll peruse through it before the break is over. The important thing is to let your mind completely rest before jumping right back in. I’d also recommend looking into methods of studying that aren’t traditionally exhausting like reading notes over and over. Some of my favorite methods are: Study Groups - get just two or three good friends to go over problems and solve them together. What’s great about these is it keeps you active while letting you immediately correct misunderstandings and learn content you might not have caught yourselfSelf-Assessment (can be in person or conducted in a group) - get friends and yourself to generate questions that are similar to what you’ve seen before in the subject/class your learning. Take advantage of flash cards if you can or even better, see if you can find an existing set from a prior year!Summarization - look over your notes and try to boil things down as far as you can. Key formulas, terms, etc. Take advantage of illustrations as well!Separate Perspectives - YouTube has a plethora of great, bite-sized explainer videos for certain topics. Try to compile together relevant material and review when you’re free (eating, commuting, etc).

Q: “What should you do if you can't study?” You should handle the primary reason students become ‘unable to learn’, become unable to study. So, you get some other person to work with you to do this until you are able to learn to do this for yourself. This is done by another person, called a Word Clearer, or more commonly a study partner or tutor. I have found teachers are not in general able to do this. The word clearer helps you locate the exact words that have caused the inability to learn and then helps you clarify them with a dictionary. This returns your ability to learn or study in each subject. The word clearer is trained to help you locate the exact word, the exact location, the exact meaning for the word that you do not understand, that will return you to doing well. When this is done systematically it is called Method One Word Clearing, or M1. I have been trained to do this. I estimate it will take 8 to 16 hours for a high school student to complete this and become able to learn again in all subjects. One can be doing well in all subjects again. This is the way I define ‘doing well.’ Doing well is when a student is flying along, feeling brilliant, enthusiastic, fully able to understand what they are learning, without stress or strain, and able to recall and apply what they have learned.This is based on the principle that the only reason a person becomes ‘unable to learn’ is that they have gone past a word that was not understood. When that word is located and properly defined they are then ‘able to learn’ again. One can learn to properly define a word with a dictionary with this book:  You should be able to locate this book at your local library, book store, ebay or Amazon. If your local library does not have one, donate one when you have completed it. Then you should take good course on how to study like The Student Hat Course (80 hours) or The Basic Study Manual.  You should then be able to return yourself to ‘doing well’ whenever you need to. For example, if a student is not ‘doing well’ for as little as 15 minutes, they should stop, locate the words they missed, clarify them, and return to ‘doing well.’ This is the correct way to study each subject. Best regards, Leon

The question is very generic, and open to several interpretations:- Is your question that you want to study (because of exams, better career goals), but cannot? Or is your question about other alternatives to studying? If it is first. Think hard and introspect, why are you not able to study? Is it because lack of interest / finding it boring? Is it because the study topic is too complex? Is it because of other external factors ( environment, personal and family life ) are affecting you? If it is because of lack of interest:i) Try to make study interesting. Read other surrounding books \ Attend other lectures on the topic. Find out why the people who spend all their life in those fields are crazy about the those subjects \ fields.   ii) If that does not work (I have had occasions like this: I hated social sciences to the core in my class X, or biology in class XII), just bite the bullet, and go through with it. There are greater rewards after that.iii) Take frequent breaks (BUT make sure you are disciplined about your timings - put an alarm if the discipline is hard to come by). In those breaks, perform activities that you really LOVE to do, something that you are really passionate about. Those breaks are very refreshing and invigorating. Of course, this varies person-to-person (some might want to cook, knit, write, play videogame, checkout quora / FB). You will come back to study with much fresher mindset. My ideal advice is to go for a short 10 minutes walk / exercise. If you find it complex:Start slowly, refresh the basics as many times as you need to. Understand smaller steps first, and then slowly feed complex stuff in your brain. NOTHING, absolutely NOTHING is complex if your brain is given adequate preparation.  If there are other external issues. Try to eliminate those issues, if you can. If noise bothers you, go to library.If you feel lonely, find study buddies. Making your study environment fixed (i.e. a comfortable chair / table, or a sofa - in your room) and developing a fixed routine also helps (wake up at 7am everyday, take shower to get ready, study for X minutes/ hours (or until you get bored). Go for a walk, study some more, take a break come back watch a TV show for 30 minutes, study more for X hours ... sleep at 11pm ).

Here is a list of suggestions which will help you improve your power of concentration: Study at the same time each day. A regular schedule can help you frame this as “study time”. Set a timer for an hour, don't allow yourself to stop studying until it goes off. Take breaks. A three minute break for every 30 minutes of study is a good guideline. Take a longer break after 90 minutes. Set goals for your session that are realistic (number of problems to solve, pages to read, etc.) When you have met one of your study goals, reward yourself with a short break. Then, return to your study area. Study in an area away from distractions such as a library, study lounge, or an empty classroom. Make sure you have everything that you need before you begin. Make sure your environment is conducive to studying, no TV, no telephone, no roommate, no boyfriend/girlfriend. Make studying an active process; take notes and make review sheets. Intersperse different kinds of study into one session, e.g. reading, writing, taking notes, memorizing, etc. Identify how what you are studying is relevant to your life. Draw connections between things you already know. Ensure that you are sleeping enough, eating well, and getting regular exercise. Your mind will be more alert, and you will be less likely to fall asleep or daydream. 83% of our sensory input comes from our eyes. To truly concentrate on something, shut your eyes and you will remove much distraction. ******************************************************************************** Some tips for studying : To memorize anything…. •	Frequently write and rewrite the notes. •	Find a partner and study with •	Walk around while studying. By walking around, you will use both your right and left brain and will memorize the thing you are studying •	Take a deep breath and look over your whole memorization course so you know what you're reading but don't try to take much in at once. •	Sit in a quiet room with appropriate natural lighting. •	Try creating a mnemonic device like a book or rhyme. Hope my answer has helped you…:D

I don't know what you are studying now. I was also in same state of mind, when I was studying my final year of engineering(BE). I decided "I can't study any more. Just I need to reach a logical end. And I am done". I finished my engineering, joined a MNC, had good time. But today, afrer 5 years, I am back to college! doing my doctoral studies.  So much water has passed by. When I sit back and think again those days and the place I am in now, I feel like laughing at myself. Immaturity, frustration, disgust, dissatisfaction and many more feelings made me to think like that, on that day. Ambition, goal, motivation and practicalities brought me back to where I am today. Here is the thing, when I feel 'I can't'  I should ask myself 'why I can't?' . This is very important. You are the right judge of yourself. There might be many reasons for someone to think  why I can't study? Like, subjects might be boring, it might be difficult to compete with peers, results are not according to the efforts or my interest lies somewhere else. Then the next question " if not studying, what else? What is goal of my life? How should achieve it?" This is very subjective and you have to figure it out and make a priority wise list of it and plan of action to achieve it. Now the important one, In your plan of action, "where does the current study fit in?" If it does not fit in, don't worry. Its time for you to change the path. But before that make sure you reach to a logical end of whatever you are doing now. Because we never know when that will be handy. For me at that time, I felt like working is better. So I choose that. Then, I felt, "I need to learn more". So I am back to school now. ;-) It might be different for you. So choose accordingly. Finally, I would like to say "Follow the heart, in the lights of Brain"

At graduation level, one might want to clear all the present papers, sometimes backlogs, get into a better workplace, etc One who is already working, wants to elevate his standard of living even more, and thus he too studies. You can start with setting weekly goals followed by a to-do list for each day to achieve your weekly goals. Make sure that you mention the “time” in your to-do list. While studying take short breaks of 5 min after every 30 - 45 minutes of study (NO phone during 5 min break). If it's difficult for you to sit at one place for 30 minutes, use a Timer (not stopwatch), Trick is to make your mind see time reducing. Give yourself some reward every time you completely follow your to-do list. You can always make someone accountable, especially if you lives with your family, ask a family member to keep a check on you during your study hours. Keep yourself motivated, watch video, listen to the person who inspires you most. The most important thing to remember is that it's not compulsory what works best for any other person will work for you too, so listen to all the suggestions and follow what works best for you. And being a professional education coach it's my personal suggestion that give a try to these recommendations and modify them the way they suit you best.

Why are you so negative? Are you a prisoner? Are you a slave? Are you a worker on an off-shore oil rig with only a small dark bunk for a personal space? Do you have a medical problem? Eyesight? Majority of the students end up in this situation and it’s completely normal. What you need to realize is that you can’t study continuously for one hour and above. Follow the 45:15 rule i.e., 45 minutes of thorough studies and 15 mins of break. This will help you study something as compared to getting bored and studying nothing at all. The ratio I’ve mentioned above is suggestive and you can make changes as per your comfort (after all, you’re the boss of your studies). However, try not to reduce the study time less than 30 minutes, and you can also reduce the break time. For example, 30:10. You’ve got to also realize that preparing for the exams will only benefit you and none other. If you feel demotivated listen to some inspirational/your favourite music. If you feel scared/anxious, perform the mindful meditation exercise wherein you should sit in a comfortable position and breathe in and out, and while doing so concentrate only on the movement of your breath in and out through the nose. At times you may get distracted, but revert your attention to the breathing. You can perform the meditation for max 10 mins. This exercise has been proven to be highly effective to reduce anxiety. Lastly, what matters the most is your study preparation and your performance during the exam, not the result. So stay calm, have some faith in yourself and you’ll do great! BEST OF LUCK!!!

Setting milestones, thinking about the consequences of gaining good marks will also help you study better. Muting your phone is important. You can even go out for a walk just to refresh yourself. This will also help you. Controlled dosage of coffee or energy drinks and rock music ( like that of Linkin Park) will also enable you stay awake in night for studying. If it is a situation where you are not able to focus, then it is a temporary phenomenon. You will be able to study well after taking some break. Take a break for a reasonable amount of time, do something not at all related to the study, such as playing a game or listening to music or dance or something. Then when you feel the break is enough you can resume the study. But if it is because there is a lack of interest in the subject or having too many questions on the subject, then you need to find out the exact reasons. Is it because it hasn't been taught well, or there are too many questions then it is time to get them answered well. Because there is no point in just studying while there are too many questions on the subject in your mind. Your next actions on finding difficulty in studying depends on the exact reasons why you are unable to study.

What do you mean “can’t?” Don’t want to? Have ADD or ADHD? Learning to study something until it yields is a habit. Habits are formed by repetitive effort. If you can train yourself to persist until you finish/find the answer/get it done you will have learned a very important life skill. Persistence is more important than talent. People who give up easily have a hard time succeeding in life. Decide if you “can’t” or “don’t want to.” The latter is a habit. A good one to change. What is your purpose in life? What do you want to spend your life doing? YOU decide—don’t let others do that for you. Once you choose your purpose, AND you have developed the habit of persistence, you will start going places.

It's a bit complicated but it will surely help you. Firstly you need to take a deep breath. Remember you inhale the maximum air and wait for sometime before exhaling. You repeat this for ten times. Then you close your eyes and turn your neck left and right. Again you need to do this for ten times. After this you slowly get up ( don't rush ). Try touching your feet without bending your waist. Do some squats as well. After you are done , sit on the bed and try to concentrate on something which you like. It can be an object , an animal or your crush. Try thinking on it as long as you can. Slowly use your right hand and touch the book which you were studying. Without much hesitation you shut it close. Then you keep it back in its place. Then you go out and play ( or do anything which relaxes your mind ).
